title: Junk Debt Buyer's Lawsuit showing two account numbers --- theirs, and the predecessor's- Is this a norm in the industry?
question: I am a Defendant in a Civil Lawsuit against a Junk debt buyer.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Hearsay in criminal cases,Admissible evidence in criminal cases,Lawsuits and disputes,Discovery,Sued for debt,Consumer protection,Evidence
answers:
Assuming you have an experienced lawyer on your side whom works in this field regularly, it is likely that you can use this situation to your benefit.

I suggest that you contact a local consumer protection (or debt defense) attorney as this question is a delicate legal issue and needs close examination.

Feel free to contact my office, Hyde & Swigart, at (619) 233-7770 with any questions or inquiries you may have. Good luck!
They have now served you discovery and I believe you can use this situation to your benefit if you have a lawyer on your side that does this regularly. Contact a debt defense attorney.

No, the company renumbering the original account for their own record keeping system is not anything you can latch onto to help your case. Company A numbers accounts a certain way, but that does not obligate Company B (who acquires the account) to use the same numbering format in their own record system. You would have a better argument if they did not include a reference to the original account number. But of course, that's exactly why they do.

It is not unheard of for accounts to be renumbered. If you do not recognize the account number, then you cannot admit that it is your account or provide other information. In California, when one doesn't know the answer to a request for admissions or to an interrogatory, it is acceptable to respond as follows: "After conducting a reasonable and good faith inquiry, respondent lacks sufficient personal knowledge to admit"; or, in the case of Interrogatories, "to respond".

I would not wait for their responses to your discovery and Bill of Particulars. There's a good chance their responses won't clear up anything. If they do, you can always amend your responses.

It is not uncommon for the account number to change after it is charged-off by the original creditor. If the account number is different from the one you had while the account was active, use that to your advantage by denying any knowledge of the account that is supposedly associated with your contract and alleged debt.

Even if the account number was the same now as before, standing is the issue that the debt buyer has the most trouble with. They claim to be the assignee of the debt, but when it comes time to prove that with admissible evidence, they cannot do it. In each and every case, the debt buyer will attempt to use a declaration or affidavit of one of their own employees, making sworn statements about the records created by the original creditor. The records are hearsay and not admissible. Make sure that you read and understand Calif. Evidence Code Sections 1271 and 1272.

Good luck!
